revision.text: {{Haskell minitoc|chapter=Monads|noexercises=1}} Using do blocks as an alternative monad syntax was first introduced way back in the [[Haskell/Simple input and output|Simple input and output]] chapter. There, we used do to sequence input/output operations, but we hadn't introduced monads yet. Now, we can see that IO is yet another monad. Since the following examples all involve IO, we will refer to the computations/monadic values as ''actions'' (as we did in the earlier parts of the book). Of course, do works with any monad; there is nothing specific about IO in how it works. == Translating the ''then'' operator == The (>>) (''then'') operator works almost identically in do notation and in unsugared code. For example, suppose we have a chain of actions like the following one: putStr "Hello" >> putStr " " >> putStr "world!" >> putStr "\n" We can rewrite that in do notation as follows: do putStr "Hello" putStr " " putStr "world!" putStr "\n" This sequence of instructions nearly matches that in any imperative language. In Haskell, we can chain any actions as long as all of them are in the same monad. In the context of the IO monad, we actions include writing to a file, opening a network connection, or asking the user for input. Here's the step-by-step translation of do notation to unsugared Haskell code: do action1 action2 action3 becomes action1 >> do action2 action3 and so on, until the do block is empty. == Translating the ''bind'' operator == The (>>=) is a bit more difficult to translate from and to do notation. (>>=) passes a value, namely the result of an action or function, downstream in the binding sequence. do notation assigns a variable name to the passed value using the <-. do x1 <- action1 x2 <- action2 action3 x1 x2 x1 and x2 are the results of action1 and action2. If, for instance, action1 is an IO Integer then x1 will be bound to an Integer). The stored values are passed as arguments to action3, which returns a third action. The do block is broadly equivalent to the following vanilla Haskell snippet: action1 >>= \ x1 -> action2 >>= \ x2 -> action3 x1 x2 The second argument of (>>=) is a function specifying what to do with the result of the action passed as first argument. Thus, chains of lambdas pass the results downstream. Remember that, without extra parentheses, a lambda extends all the way to the end of the expression. x1 is still in scope at the point we call action3. We can rewrite the chain of lambdas more legibly by using separate lines and indentation: action1 >>= \ x1 -> action2 >>= \ x2 -> action3 x1 x2 That shows the scope of each lamdba function clearly. To group things more like the do notation, we could show it like this: action1 >>= \ x1 -> action2 >>= \ x2 -> action3 x1 x2 These presentation differences are only a matter of assisting readability.Actually, the indentation isn't needed in this case. This is equally valid: action1 >>= \ x1 -> action2 >>= \ x2 -> action3 x1 x2 Of course, we could use even more indentation if we wanted. Here's an extreme example: action1 >>= \ x1 -> action2 >>= \ x2 -> action3 x1 x2 While that indention is certainly overkill, it could be worse: action1 >>= \ x1 -> action2 >>= \ x2 -> action3 x1 x2 That is valid Haskell but is baffling to read; so please don't ever write like that. Write your code with consistent and meaningful groupings. === The ''fail'' method === Above, we said the snippet with lambdas was "broadly equivalent" to the do block. The translation is not exact because the do notation adds special handling of pattern match failures. When placed at the left of either <- or ->, x1 and x2 are patterns being matched. Therefore, if action1 returned a Maybe Integer we could write a do block like this... do Just x1 <- action1 x2 <- action2 action3 x1 x2 ...and x1 be an Integer. In such a case, what happens if action1 returns Nothing? Ordinarily, the program would crash with an non-exhaustive patterns error, just like the one we get when calling head on an empty list. With do notation, however, failures are handled with the fail method for the relevant monad. The do block above translates to: action1 >>= f where f (Just x1) = do x2 <- action2 action3 x1 x2 f _ = fail "..." -- A compiler-generated message. What fail actually does depends on the monad instance. Though it will often rethrow the pattern matching error, monads that incorporate some sort of error handling may deal with the failure in their own specific ways. For instance, Maybe has {{nowrap|1=fail _ = Nothing}}; analogously, for the list monad {{nowrap|1=fail _ = []}}.This explains why, as we pointed out in the [[Haskell/Pattern_matching#List_comprehensions|"Pattern matching" chapter]], pattern matching failures in list comprehensions are silently ignored. The fail method is an artifact of do notation. Rather than calling fail directly, you should rely on automatic handling of pattern match failures whenever you are sure that fail will do something sensible for the monad you are using. == Example: user-interactive program == {{Body note|We are going to interact with the user, so we will use putStr and getLine alternately. To avoid unexpected results in the output, we must disable output buffering when importing System.IO. To do this, put hSetBuffering stdout NoBuffering at the top of your code. To handle this otherwise, you would explicitly flush the output buffer before each interaction with the user (namely a getLine) using hFlush stdout. If you are testing this code with ghci, you don't have such problems.}} Consider this simple program that asks the user for their first and last names: nameDo :: IO () nameDo = do putStr "What is your first name? " first <- getLine putStr "And your last name? " last <- getLine let full = first ++ " " ++ last putStrLn ("Pleased to meet you, " ++ full ++ "!") A possible translation into vanilla monadic code: nameLambda :: IO () nameLambda = putStr "What is your first name? " >> getLine >>= \ first -> putStr "And your last name? " >> getLine >>= \ last -> let full = first ++ " " ++ last in putStrLn ("Pleased to meet you, " ++ full ++ "!") In cases like this, where we just want to chain several actions, the imperative style of do notation feels natural and convenient. In comparison, monadic code with explicit binds and lambdas is something of an acquired taste. Notice that example above includes a let statement in the do block. The de-sugared version is simply a regular let expression where the in part is whatever follows from the do syntax. == Returning values == The last statement in do notation is the overall result of the do block. In the previous example, the result was of the type IO (), i.e. an empty value in the IO monad. Suppose that we want to rewrite the example but return an IO String with the acquired name. All we need to do is add a return: nameReturn :: IO String nameReturn = do putStr "What is your first name? " first <- getLine putStr "And your last name? " last <- getLine let full = first ++ " " ++ last putStrLn ("Pleased to meet you, " ++ full ++ "!") return full This example will "return" the full name as a string inside the IO monad, which can then be utilized downstream elsewhere: greetAndSeeYou :: IO () greetAndSeeYou = do name <- nameReturn putStrLn ("See you, " ++ name ++ "!") Here, nameReturn will be run and the returned result (called "full" in the nameReturn function) will be assigned to the variable "name" in our new function. The greeting part of nameReturn will be printed to the screen because that is part of the calculation process. Then, the additional "see you" message will print as well, and the final returned value is back to being IO (). If you know imperative languages like C, you might think return in Haskell matches return elsewhere. A small variation on the example will dispel that impression: nameReturnAndCarryOn = do putStr "What is your first name? " first <- getLine putStr "And your last name? " last <- getLine let full = first++" "++last putStrLn ("Pleased to meet you, "++full++"!") return full putStrLn "I am not finished yet!" The string in the extra line ''will'' be printed out because return is ''not'' a final statement interrupting the flow (as it would be in C and other languages). Indeed, the type of nameReturnAndCarryOn is IO (), — the type of the final putStrLn action. After the function is called, the IO String created by the return full will disappear without a trace. == Just sugar == As a syntactical convenience, do notation does not add anything essential, but it is often preferable for clarity and style. However, do is never used for a single action. The Haskell "Hello world" is simply: main = putStrLn "Hello world!" Snippets like this one are totally redundant: fooRedundant = do x <- bar return x Thanks to the [[Haskell/Monads#Monad_Laws|monad laws]], we can and should write simply: foo = bar A subtle but crucial point relates to function composition: As we already know, the greetAndSeeYou action in the section just above could be rewritten as: greetAndSeeYou :: IO () greetAndSeeYou = nameReturn >>= \ name -> putStrLn ("See you, " ++ name ++ "!") While you might find the lambda a little unsightly, suppose we had a printSeeYou function defined elsewhere: printSeeYou :: String -> IO () printSeeYou name = putStrLn ("See you, " ++ name ++ "!") Now, we can have a clean function definition with neither lambdas or do: greetAndSeeYou :: IO () greetAndSeeYou = nameReturn >>= printSeeYou Or, if we had a ''non-monadic'' seeYou function: seeYou :: String -> String seeYou name = "See you, " ++ name ++ "!" Then we can write: -- Reminder: liftM f m == m >>= return . f == fmap f m greetAndSeeYou :: IO () greetAndSeeYou = liftM seeYou nameReturn >>= putStrLn Keep this last example with liftM in mind; we will soon return to using non-monadic functions in monadic code, and liftM will be useful there. {{Haskell/NotesSection}} {{Haskell navigation|chapter=Monads|noexercises=1}} {{BookCat}}

{{recipe}} {{cookwork|Some of the ingredients and instructions for the recipe are apparently missing. For example, there are no liquids with which to make a dough to form into a 'plate roll' whatever that may be.}} ==Ingredients== * 125g of raw (non-peeled and not toasted) almonds * 1 egg * 150g of [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 100g of sugar * 1 lemon * teaspoon of [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * teaspoon of yeast
===Procedure=== #Clean the lemon and grate its peel. #Mix the grated peel into the flour, sugar, cinnamon and yeast. #Add the almonds. Form two plate rolls of about 6 cm x 3 cm. #Beat the egg and brush it onto the plate rolls. #Bake in the oven at a moderate heat (180ºC) for 25 minutes. #While still hot, cut into thin slices of one centimetre or less. #Cook them for five minutes more in the oven to brown their surfaces. #Allow to cool before eating.
[[Category:Dessert recipes]]

revision.comment: fixing dead links
revision.text:
The '''Messier objects''' are a set of astronomical objects first listed by French astronomer [[w:Charles Messier|Charles Messier]] in his "Catalogue des Nébuleuses et des Amas d'Étoiles" ("Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters") included in the ''Connaissance des Temps'' for 1774 (published in 1771). The original motivation of the catalogue was that Messier was a comet hunter, and was frustrated by objects which resembled but were not comets. He therefore compiled a list of these objects,{{cite web | title=SEDS Messier Database | work=THE MESSIER CATALOG | url=http://seds.org/messier/ | accessdate=2007-11-10}} in collaboration with his assistant Pierre Méchain. The first edition covered 45 objects numbered M1 to M45. The total list published by Messier finally contained 103 objects, but the list "got an independent life" by successive additions by other astronomers, motivated by side notes in Messier's and Mechain's texts indicating that either of them knew of the objects. The first such addition came from [[w:Camille Flammarion|Camille Flammarion]] in 1921, who added M104 after finding Messiers side note in his 1781 edition exemplar of the catalogue. M105 to M107 were added by [[w:Helen Sawyer Hogg|Helen Sawyer Hogg]] in 1947, M108 and M109 by [[w:Owen Gingerich|Owen Gingerich]] in 1960, and M110 by [[w:Kenneth Glyn Jones|Kenneth Glyn Jones]].The Guinness Book of Astronomy, [[w:Patrick Moore|Patrick Moore]] and Guinness Superlatives Ltd 1979, ISBN 09-00-42476-1 M102 was observed by Méchain, who communicated his notes to Messier; later, it was noted by Méchain himself that this object does not exist, and it was simply a re-observation of M101. Some sources mention the galaxy NGC 5866 as an identification for M102, but its description does not fit with Méchain's notes. Messier's final catalogue was included in the ''Connaissance des Temps'' for 1784 (published in 1781).Charles Messier, 1781. Catalogue des Nébuleuses & des amas d'Étoiles. Connoissance des Temps for 1784 (published 1781), pp. 227-267 [Bibcode: 1781CdT..1784..227M]
{{cite web | title=Original Messier Catalog of 1781 | work=Original Messier Catalog of 1781 | url=http://seds.org/messier/xtra/Mcat/mcat1781.html#messier1781 | accessdate=2007-11-10|archiveurl=https://archive.is/Ad5i|archivedate=2012-06-29}} These objects are still known by their '''Messier number''' from this list. Because Messier lived and did his astronomical work in France in the Northern Hemisphere, the list he compiled contains only objects from the north celestial pole to a celestial latitude of about –35.7°. Many impressive Southern objects, such as the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds are excluded from the list. All of the Messier objects are visible with binoculars or small telescopes (under favorable conditions); therefore they are popular viewing objects for amateur astronomers. In early spring, astronomers sometimes gather for "Messier marathons", when all of the objects can be viewed over a single night.{{cite web | title=The Messier Marathon | work=THE MESSIER MARATHON | url=http://seds.org/messier/xtra/marathon/marathon.html | accessdate=2007-11-10|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/19990218182156/http://seds.org/messier/xtra/marathon/marathon.html|archivedate=1999-02-18}} A summary of the astrophysics of each Messier object, as well as all of the objects in the [[w:Herschel 400 Catalog|Herschel 400 Catalog]], can be found in ''Concise Catalog of Deep-sky Objects: Astrophysical Information for 500 Galaxies, Clusters and Nebulae'' by W. H. Finlay, ISBN 1-85233-691-9. {{Messier Index}} {| |- style="vertical-align:top;" | style="width:50%"| ==References== {{reflist|2}} | style="width:50%"| ==External links== * [http://www.seds.org/messier/ SEDS Messier Database] :* [http://www.seds.org/messier/xtra/history/CMessier.html Charles Messier] :* [http://www.seds.org/messier/xtra/history/m-cat.html Charles Messier's Catalog of Nebulae and Star Clusters] * [http://web.archive.org/web/19990420195402/http://seds.org/messier/xtra/history/mcathist.html History of the Messier Catalog] * [http://zebu.uoregon.edu/messier.html CCD Images of Messier Objects] * [http://www.12dstring.me.uk/messiercatalogue.htm 12 Dimensional String] * [http://messier45.com/messier/index.html Messier Gallery] * [http://www.space-and-telescope.com/MessierObjects.aspx The Messier Catalogue] |} __NOTOC__ __NOEDITSECTION__ [[fr:Mini-guide du catalogue Messier]]

Welcome ! ! !
revision.text:
== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 17:58, 19 August 2009 (UTC)

revision.text:
== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 17:58, 19 August 2009 (UTC)

PS: I've restored some of the changes you made (C++, dealing with the extension of header files), since it was a statement of a convention used on all the book, if agreed upon, altering it would result in a major work. revision.comment: Welcome!
revision.text:
== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Bumbulski!
[[Image:Crystal Clear app korganizer.png|20px]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for freely-licensed collaboratively-developed [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].'''
You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' about the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[Wikibooks:Reading room/General|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Projects|interests you]]. If you're coming here from other Wikimedia projects, you should read [[Help:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|our primer for Wikimedians]] to get quickly up-to-speed.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* See the '''Wikibooks [[Help:Contents|help pages]]''' for common issues, or read [[Using Wikibooks]] for a more user-friendly introduction to the project. * Remember, every edit is saved, so if you make mistakes, you can [[Wikibooks:Reverting|revert]] to an earlier version if needed. * Get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * You cannot upload an image until you have been a member for at least '''4 days'''. If your upload is tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] and source citation are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]].
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[:w:Help:Edit summary|the edit summary]] and [[Help:Show preview|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[Help:Talk page|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
Thanks, [[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|talk]]) 19:32, 19 August 2009 (UTC)
(P.S. Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)

([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck!
PS: Fixed that issue on the C++ Programming. Thanks for pointing that out. Nnext time you should use the talk page associated or add a TODO (template) next to the issue (if you don't understand templates see the edit history of that page, I used it to quick fix the comment you posted on the book, anyway good work... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 00:06, 20 August 2009 (UTC)
PPS: I've examined it closely and the compiler you are using probably isn't up-to-date. I considered that you didn't remove the previous for loop, since then the variable cur_month wouldn't exist in the code (and it wouldn't/shouldn't compile at all), since it did the compiler must be ignoring the scope of the for loop, as the first loop declares and defines it in scope (it shouldn't be recognized outside of it) as it was, hence enabling you to compile the example, the most problematic error is in the compiler itself. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 01:30, 20 August 2009 (UTC)

revision.comment: Beef to Ground Beef cat, per the recipe.
revision.text:
{{recipe}}
If you can't stand the heat, you may, of course, turn down the cayenne.
== Ingredients == * 1 pound ground chuck * 1-1 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper * 1/2 tsp salt * 1/2 tsp freshly ground black pepper * 1 tsp Montreal Steak Seasoning * Olive oil * 8 slices bacon, crisp cooked * 4 slices pepper jack cheese * Lettuce, tomato, and onion (optional) * 1/2 cup mayonnaise * 2 chipotle chile in adobo, finely chopped
== Procedure == #Combine mayo and chipotle. Refrigerate until needed. #Combine cayenne, salt, pepper, and seasoning. Set aside. #Form meat into 4 equal patties, about 1/2 inch thick. Make an indentation in the center of each one and brush with olive oil. #Sprinkle patties on both sides with seasoning mixture. Set aside. #Preheat a chimney starter full of charcoal in the bottom of a kettle grill. Once hot, disperse evenly around the bottom of the grill. #Add burgers and grill, turning often, until desired "doneness" is achieved. #Place a slice of cheese on each patty once it comes off the grill. Serve with bacon, lettuce, tomato, and chipotle mayo on buns.
[[Category:Ground beef recipes]] [[Category:Bacon recipes]] [[Category:Cheese recipes]] [[Category:Chile recipes]] [[Category:Sandwich recipes]] [[Category:Grilled recipes]] [[Category:American recipes]]

Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 06:07, 20 August 2009 (UTC)

revision.text:
= Armenia = * The country was a region of the former Soviet Union and became an independent country in 1991. * Meter stamps with Soviet Union markings continued to be used in Armenia after independence. See SOVIET UNION for these stamps. * Only one stamp inscribed “ARMENIA” has been seen so far. ----
[[File:Armenia stamp type 1.jpg|left|343px]] '''1. Hasler “Mailmaster”''' (MV). : Horizontal frank with panels at top, bottom and sides. : At top, “A” and “M” flanking oval logo. : “POST” stacked at right, Armenian characters stacked at left. : Country name at bottom in Armenian (left) and English (right). : M# with “AH” prefix breaks bottom frame line. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|10px]]00000 ---- {{BookCat}}

== Hyundai's VIN format ==
For Model Years 2012
{| class="wikitable" !Position !Sample !colspan="2"|Description |- |1 |K |rowspan="3"|[[#Hyundai WMIs|WMI]] |[[#Geographic zone|Geographic zone]] |- |2 |M |[[#Manufacturer|Manufacturer]] |- |3 |H |[[#Vehicle Type|Vehicle Type]] |- |4 |D |rowspan="6"|[[#Vehicle Descriptor Section|VDS]] |[[#Model Line or Drive Type|Model Line or Drive Type]] |- |5 |H |[[#Body Type or Trim Level|Body Type or Trim Level]] |- |6 |4 |[[#Trim Level or Body Type|Trim Level or Body Type]] |- |7 |1 |[[#Restraint Systems or GVWR|Restraint Systems or GVWR]] |- |8 |E |[[#Engine Type|Engine Type]] |- |9 |9 |[[../../Check Digit|Check Digit]] |- |10 |E |rowspan="8"|[[#Vehicle Identifier Section|VIS]] |[[../../Model Year|Model Year]] |- |11 |U |[[#Manufacturing Plant Code|Manufacturing Plant Code]] |- |12 |9 |rowspan=6|Serial Number |- |13 |3 |- |14 |8 |- |15 |2 |- |16 |9 |- |17 |4 |}
==Hyundai WMIs (positions 1-3) == * AC5 = Hyundai Automotive South Africa (cars) * ADD = Hyundai Automotive South Africa (SUV) * KMH = Hyundai Korea (passenger vehicle) * KM8 = Hyundai Korea (multi-purpose vehicle) * KND = Hyundai Motor Group (multi-purpose vehicle) * MAL = Hyundai Motors India Ltd * NLH = Hyundai Assan (passenger cars) * NLJ = Hyundai Assan (minibus, van) * TMA = Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Czech * U6Z = Kia Motors Slovakia (ix35 only) * Z94 = Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Rus * ZK5 = Hyundai Automobili Italia Importazioni * 2HM = Hyundai Canada * 3H3 = Hyundai de Mexico SA de CV * 5NM = Hyundai USA (Multi-Passenger Vehicle) Alabama * 5NP = Hyundai USA (Passenger Vehicle) Alabama * 9?? = Hyundai Motor Brasil * 9?? = Caoa Montadora (old Tucson and HR trucks for Brazil only)
===Geographic Zone (position 1)=== * A * K = Asia (South Korea) * M = Asia (India) * N = Asia (Turkey) * T = Europe (Czech Republic) * U * Z * 2 = Canada * 3 = North America (Mexico) * 5 = USA * 9 = South America (Brazil)
===Manufacturer (position 2)=== * A = HMI (Hyundai Motor India) * C * D * H = Bromont Assembly Plant, Canada * K * L = HAOS (Hyundai Assan Otomotiv Sanayi), Turkey * M = HMC (Hyundai Motor Company), South Korea * N = HMMA (Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama), USA * 6 * 9
===Vehicle Type (position 3)=== * A * B = Trailer * C = Special car * D = Recreational * E = Tractor * F = Truck, van * H = Passenger car, MPV, RV * J = Minibus, bus, semi-MPV * L * M * N = Truck, bus, van * X = Passenger car, MPV, RV * Y = Bus * Z = Truck, van * 3 * 4 * 5 * 8 = MPV
==Vehicle Descriptor Section== ===Model Line and Drive Type (position 4)=== *B = Getz *C = Accent 00 – *D = Elantra 01 – *E = Sonata 06 – *F = XG300 01, XG350 02 – 05, Azera 06 – *G = Genesis, 09 – *H = Tiburon 03 – 08, Genesis Coupe 09- *J = Elantra 96 – 00, Tiburon 97 – 01, Tucson 05 - *M = Entourage 07 – *N = Veracruz 07 – *S = Santa Fe 01 – *T = Veloster *V = Accent 97-99 *W = Sonata 99 - 05
==Vehicle Descriptor Section== ===Body Type or Trim Level (position 5) === Body Type (96 – 00 Models except 00 Accent, incl.01 – 05 Sonata, 01 Tiburon) *A = 5-door hatchback *D = 3-door hatchback *E = 2-door sedan *F = 4-door sedan *G = 2-door couple *W = 5-door wagon Trim Level (All 01 – 09 Models, except 01 – 05 Sonata, 01 Tiburon, incl. 00 Accent) *B = GL Santa Fe, 01 – 04; 3.8L Genesis, 09 – *C = GLS Santa Fe, 01 – 06; Limited Santa Fe, 06; SE Azera, 06 – 07; Limited Azera, 06 –; GLS Azera, 07 –; SE Entourage, 07; GLS or Limited Entourage, 07 –; 4.6L Genesis, 09 –; Elantra Touring, 09 –, Base Veloster, 12- *F = Base or L Accent, 00 – 04 *G = GL or GS Accent, 00 – 04; GT Accent, 03 – 05; GLS Accent, 05; = GLS Santa Fe, 07 – *H = SE or Limited Santa Fe, 07 *M = GL (Base) Tiburon, 03 – 04; GS Tiburon, 05 – 08; GL Tucson, 05 – 06; GLS Tucson, 07 –; GS Accent, 07 – *N = GLS Accent, 06 –; SE Accent, 07 –; GLS or GT Elantra, 01 – 06; Limited Elantra, 06; GLS Tucson, 05 – 06; LX Tucson, 05; Limited Tucson, 06 –; SE Tucson 07 –; Limited V6 Tucson, 08 –; GT Tiburon, 03 – 08; SE Tiburon, 05 – 08; GT Limited Tiburon, 06 – 08 *T = GL Sonata, 06; GLS Sonata, 07 – *U = GLS (Base or L) XG300, 01; XG350, 02 – 05; GLS or LX Sonata, 06; Limited Sonata, 06 –; SE Sonata, 07 –; Limited Elantra, 07; GLS or SE Elantra, 07 –; GLS, Limited Veracruz, 07 –; SE, Veracruz, 07
==Vehicle Descriptor Section== ===Trim Level or Body Type (position 6)=== Trim Level (96-00 Medels except 00 Accent, incl. 01-05, Sonata, 01 Tiburon) *1 = base *2 = GL *3= GLS, LS, LX, or GS Body Trim (all 01-09 Models, except 01-05 Sonata, 01 Tiburon, incl. 00 Accent) *1 = wagon FWD *2 = minivan (Long Coach) *3 = 3 door hatchback *4 = 4 door sedan *5 = 5 door hatchback *6 = coupe *7 = wagon FWD *8 = wagon
==Vehicle Descriptor Section== ===Restraint System or GVWR (position 7)=== Restraint System (Passenger) *1 = Active 3-point *2 = Passive *3 = Driver-side airbag (manual belt) passenger-side passive *4 = Dual airbags (manual belts) *5 = Depowered airbags *6 = Advanced airbags or depowered airbags with suppression GVWR (Multi-Purpose Vehicle) *2 = GVWR Class C (4,001-5,000 lbs) *3 = GVWR Class D (5,001-6,000 lbs)
==Vehicle Descriptor Section== ===Engine Type (position 8)=== *B = 1975 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Tucson, 05 -, 2351 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Santa Fe, 01 - 04 *C = 1599 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Accent, 01 -, 2359 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Sonata, 06 -, 3778 cc DOHC V6. Veracruz, 07 -; 1591 cc DOHC 4 cyl. FFV (E22/E100) HB20 12-, *D = 1975 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Elantra, 01-, 1975 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Tiburon, 03 – 08, 2656 cc DOHC V6 Santa Fe, 01 -, 2656 cc DOHC V6 Tucson, 05 -, 2972 cc DOHC V6 XG300, 01 –, 3342 cc DOHC V6 Azera, 07I30 13-; 1998 cc DOHC 4 cyl. FFV (E22/E100) Tucson/IX35 12-,1591 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Veloster. *E = 3497 cc DOHC V6 XG350, 02 - 05, 3497 cc DOHC V6 Santa Fe, 03 - 06, 3342 cc DOHC V6 Santa Fe, 07 -, 3778 cc DOHC V6 Genesis, 09 – *F = 1975 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Accent, 97 – 01, 1975 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Accent, 99 - 00, 2656 cc DOHC V6 Tiburon, 03 - 08, 3342 cc DOHC V6 Sonata, 06 -, 3778 cc DOHC V6 Azera, 06 -, 4627 cc DOHC V8 Genesis, 09 - *G = 1495 cc SOHC 4 cyl. Accent, 00 - 02 *H = 2656 cc DOHC V6 Sonata, 02 - 05 *L = 1349 cc SOHC 4 Accent, 97-98 *S = 2351 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Sonata, 99 - 05 *V = 2493 cc DOHC V6 Sonata, 99 - 01 *3 = 3778 cc DOHC V6 Entourage, 07 - *M = Sonata 1999 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Tucson, 05 -, 2351 cc DOHC 4 cyl. Santa Fe, 01 - 04
==Vehicle Identifier Section== ===Manufacturing Plant Code (position 11)=== * A = Asan, Korea * B = Bromont, Canada (2HM) / Gabarone, Botswana (KMH) / Anapolis, Goiás, Brazil (Caoa Montadora plant) * C = Changwon, Korea. Cheonju, Korea * H = Montgomery, Alabama, USA * J = Nošovice, Czech Republic (TMA) / East London, South Africa (AC5/ADD) * K = Gwangju, Korea (Kia plant) * L = Žilina, Slovakia (Kia plant) * M = Chennai, India * P = Piracicaba, São Paulo, Brazil (Hyundai Motor Brasil plant) * R = Sankt Petersburg, Russia * U = Ulsan, Korea * W = Los Angeles, USA * Z = İzmit, Turkey * 5 = Osnabrück, Germany (Karmann, KNA) / Žilina, Slovakia (Kia plant, KNE) * 6 = Sohari, Korea
==References== * http://www.vindecoderz.com/EN/Hyundai * http://www.myhyundaiforums.com/08-GI-002pdf.pdf Updated Reference Added * http://www.hyundai.auto.ru/vin.pdf OLD * http://www.newtiburon.com/forums/showthread.php?t=43974 * http://www.paul128.co.kr/paul/car/hdinfo.html * http://www.genracer.com/hyundai-vin-decoder/ * http://www.aiam.org/vin/2000VINBOOK.pdf * http://www.scribd.com/doc/4712367/VIN * http://www.nhtsa.dot.gov/cars/rules/manufacture/

revision.comment: moved [[Wikibooks:Votes for deletion/Frankenstein]] to [[Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Frankenstein]]: Per [[Wikibooks_talk:Votes_for_deletion#Page_rename_proposal]]
revision.text: <noinclude>==Frankenstein==</noinclude> {{closed|Closed as [[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete'''. Author contacted, no response. Several votes for deletion. With only links to nonexistent numbered chapters, it appears that this meets everyone's criteria for deletion. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 12:38, 20 August 2009 (UTC)}} There is no content written here, just an outline of chapters to comment on. No one seems to have edited it in about one year. [[User:Thenub314|Thenub314]] ([[User talk:Thenub314|talk]]) 14:58, 5 July 2009 (UTC) :{{comment}} Looks like it's intended to be the framework for a class project... contact the main author and see what he intends? [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] <small>([[User talk:Chazz|talk]])</small> 17:13, 7 July 2009 (UTC) ::{{comment}} [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] has tagged his page (Thank you!), and there was no link to email him. But given that he only has 3 edits within 20 minutes of each other from over a year ago, I would be surprised if word reaches him. But I'll keep my fingers crossed. [[User:Thenub314|Thenub314]] ([[User talk:Thenub314|talk]]) 18:33, 7 July 2009 (UTC) :{{comment}} Should stub-hood be grounds for deletion, if the book has potential to be developed into something worthwhile at some point down the road? I see two obstacles to this being developed by someone else later, neither of which strikes me as deletion-worthy: the subject is specialized enough that there is a limited pool of people able to develop it (but that's true of many wikibooks); and potential developers wouldn't notice it because it isn't cataloged (but that can be fixed). --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|talk]]) 17:56, 7 July 2009 (UTC) :{{comment}} I wasn't sure what our exact policy is about old stubs. On the one hand over at the maintenance page it says "Old stubs may be removed or submitted to WB:VFD." However the deletion policy seems to say "In general, keep stubs" and mentions nothing about age. Stub-hood alone definitely shouldn't be grounds for deletion. But do we want to allow for the possibility of deleting old stubs (Maybe one year simply isn't long enough to wait?)[[User:Thenub314|Thenub314]] ([[User talk:Thenub314|talk]]) 18:26, 7 July 2009 (UTC) :{{comment}} Doesn't this article resemble [[The Old Man and the Sea]]? [[User:Kayau|Kayau]] ([[User talk:Kayau|talk]]) 11:03, 20 July 2009 (UTC) :[[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete''' I'm all for defending stubs but this is an empty stub from August 2008. It has no content nor any useful structure one could use to build upon, there will be no loss in deleting the thing... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 15:53, 3 August 2009 (UTC) :[[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete''' These annotated text stubs with only red links or empty heading sections only make Wikibooks look bad and disappoint readers who click on a book hoping for content, only to find none whatsoever. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 01:11, 4 August 2009 (UTC) : [[File:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete''' No meaningful content. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 19:28, 16 August 2009 (UTC) {{end closed}}

revision.comment: moved [[Wikibooks:Votes for deletion/Pavlova]] to [[Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Pavlova]]: Per [[Wikibooks_talk:Votes_for_deletion#Page_rename_proposal]]
revision.text:
<noinclude>==Pavlova==</noinclude>
{{closed|Closed as [[File:Symbol merge vote.svg|15px]] '''history merge''' of a redundant page into a more developed one.  This avoids any loss of attribution and eliminates duplication of efforts at two different pages. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 13:18, 20 August 2009 (UTC)}}
This version of this recipe in the Cookbook seems to be the same, and the history giving in [[:Cookbook:Pavlova]] seems to coincide better with the history given at wikipedia, which seems well referenced.  Overall I am left with the feeling that there is nothing to merge and this page may be safely deleted. [[User:Thenub314|Thenub314]] ([[User talk:Thenub314|talk]]) 17:40, 10 August 2009 (UTC)
:'''Delete''' Redundant and out of place [[User:Geoff Plourde|Geoff Plourde]] ([[User talk:Geoff Plourde|talk]]) 19:04, 10 August 2009 (UTC)
{{end closed}}

revision.comment: /* GROUP PO: Stamps from post office franking machines */ --~~~~
revision.text:
= Aruba = The first meter inscribed ARUBA appears in 1986 after it separated from the Dutch Federation of Netherlands Antilles. See NETHERLANDS ANTILLES for issues prior to 1986. The stamps are grouped according to function: : '''A''' - Private business use : '''PO''' - Post office machine stamps ---- == GROUP A: Stamps used by businesses and private enterprise ==
[[File:Aruba stamp type A1.jpg|left|330px]] '''A1. 1986, Pitney Bowes-GB “5000” series''' (MV), 1986. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Horizontal frank with frame lines at top and bottom and short horizontal : dashes along right side. Value figures contained in a complete box. : Large Aruba star above three stacked horizontal lines between TM and : value box. M# with “P.B.” prefix below star and lines. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][[File:MeterCat triad.jpg|12px]]0.00 [[File:Aruba A2.jpg|left|315px]] '''A2. Pitney Bowes-GB “6300” series''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] : Similar to Type A1, but value box is open at top and left. : The Aruba star has two lines above and below. : M# with “P.B.’ prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][[File:MeterCat triad.jpg|12px]]0.00 [[File:Aruba stamp type A3.jpg|left|340px]] '''A3. Pitney Bowes-GB “A900” series''' (MV). : As Type A2, but frank is wider and value figures are larger. : The Aruba star has four lines above and below. : M# with “P.B.’ prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][[File:MeterCat triad.jpg|12px]]00.00 [[File:Aruba A4.jpg|left|315px]] '''A4. Francotyp “Cc”''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] : Upright frank with single-line frame. M# with “FT” prefix : breaks bottom frame line. Be-tween value figures and M# : are the Aruba star and five stacked horizontal lines. : TM: SL with ornamental pattern at sides. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][[File:MeterCat solid diamond.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:Aruba stamp type A5.jpg|left|340px]] '''A5. Neopost “Electronic”''' (MV). : Square frank with single-line frame. : M# with “RA” prefix breaks bottom frame line. : Above the M# are three stacked horizontal lines. : The Aruba star is at bottom left. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][[File:MeterCat triad.jpg|12px]]0.00 [[File:Aruba stamp type A6.jpg|left|330px]]
'''A6. Postalia "D3”''' (MV). : Frank without exterior frame lines. : Country name at top, star and four parallel lines at bottom. : Without meter number. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000



---- ---- == GROUP PO: Stamps from post office franking machines ==
[[File: Aruba stamp type PO1.jpg|left|370px]] '''PO1. Massad''' (digital). : Preprinted design is predominantly blue with some red. : The arms of the country at left with “Postal Services” : above and “ARUBA” below. The value figures appear in a : white rectangle at right. Below the frank is a large : field to contain a registration number with large red : “R” at left. The value figures and other data are added : in purple at point of sale. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]](000)0.00 [[File:Aruba stamp type PO2.jpg|left|330px]] '''PO2. Massad''' (digital). : Similar in design to Type PO1, but the design is predominantly gray. : The arms of the country stand alone at left. “ARUBA” and “POSTAGE PAID” : are below the value figures in the box at right. “POSTAL SERVICES/ ARUBA” : is above the value box. Below the frank is a large field to contain a : registration number with large red “R” at left. The value figures and : other data are added in purple at point of sale. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]](000)0.00 [[File:Aruba stamp type PO3.jpg|left|330px]] [[File:Aruba stamp type PO3 (Papiamento).jpg|left|330px]]

'''PO3''' Unknown (digital). : Plain, self-adhesive label with rounded corners. : "POST ARUBA N.V." at top, above a slogan in English or the local language, Papiamento. : Below the slogan: :::::::::::::::::: * date, time, identification number :::::::::::::::::: * town at left, mail clerk's(?) name above the weight :::::::::::::::::: * mail classification :::::::::::::::::: * "Total Sum :" and value figures : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]AWG0.00






{{BookCat}}

page.title: International Postage Meter Stamp Catalog/Ascension Island

revision.text:
= Ascension Island =
* Ascension Island is part of the British overseas territory of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha. It has a population of only about 900 permanent inhabitants and so has only a minor need for postage meters. Although it does issue traditional postage stamps no postage meters are known to be used on this South Atlantic island. ----

Created page with 'Lorin's Page'

revision.text:
Please add, update, order, and otherwise evolve this list! Wikipedia links are included for background.
Please be aware that some acronyms may be rephrased to suit the context. For example, AFM is listed here so as to refer to the Atomic Force Microscope itself, but AFM may also refer to the process of performing Atomic Force Microscopy. Should common prefixes be given their own places?
At the moment, this is not meant as an extensive list of techniques or processes relevant to nanotechnology. Instead it is meant to be a [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosetta_Stone 'Rosetta stone'] for those unfamiliar with this jargon.
==Acronyms==
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_force_microscope AFM] - Atomic Force Microscope
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_Layer_Deposition ALD] - Atomic Layer Deposition (''idem'' Any Layer Deposition)
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copper_indium_gallium_selenide CIGS] - Copper Indium Gallium Selenide
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_nanotubes CNT] - Carbon nanotube
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_vapor_deposition CVD] - Chemical Vapor Depositon
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_scanning_calorimetry DSC] - Differential Scanning Calorimetry
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_nanotubes#Multi-walled DWNT] - Double-walled carbon nanotubes
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electron_beam_physical_vapor_deposition EB-PVD] - Electron Beam Physical Vapor Deposition
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electron_beam_lithography EBDW] - Electron-Beam Direct-Write Lithography
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electron_energy_loss_spectroscopy EELS] - Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_metal_atom_chains EMAC] - Extended metal atom chains
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_ultraviolet_lithography EUV] - Extreme Ultraviolet Lithography
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indium_tin_oxide ITO] - Indium Tin Oxide
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MOCVD MOCVD] - Metal Organic Chemical Vapor Deposition (''idem'' Metalorganic Vapor Phase Epitaxy)
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_nanotubes#Multi-walled MWNT] - Multi-walled nanotubes
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanoelectromechanical_systems NEMS] - Nanoelectromechanical systems
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanolithography NIL] - Nanoimprint Lithography
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_nanotubes#Fullerite P-SWNT] - Polymerized single-walled nanotubes
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PECVD PECVD] - Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulsed_laser_deposition PLD] - Pulsed Laser Deposition (''idem'' Pulsed Laser Ablation)
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_vapor_deposition PVD] - Physical Vapor Deposition
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive-ion_etching RIE] - Reactive Ion Etching
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selected_area_diffraction SAED] - Selected Area Electron Diffraction
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scanning_electron_microscope SEM] - Scanning Electron Microscope
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secondary_ion_mass_spectrometry SIMS] - Secondary Ion Mass Spectroscopy
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanowire SiNW] - Silicon Nanowire
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scanning_probe_lithography SPL] - Scanning Probe Lithography
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_nanotubes#Single-walled SWNT] - Single-walled nanotubes
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scanning_transmission_electron_microscopy STEM] - Scanning Transmission Electron Microscope
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scanning_tunneling_microscope STM] - Scanning Tunneling Microscope
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmission_electron_microscopy TEM] - Transmission Electron Microscope
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UV/VIS_spectroscopy UV/Vis] - Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vapor-Liquid-Solid_method VLS] - Vapor-liquid-solid method (used to create one-dimensional structures)
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-ray_photoelectron_spectroscopy XPS] - X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XRD XRD] - X-ray Diffraction
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YBCO YBCO] - Yttrium Barium Copper Oxide
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Welcome ! ! !
revision.text:
== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 19:54, 20 August 2009 (UTC)

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]]. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 19:54, 20 August 2009 (UTC)

CSS offers various ways of setting the appearance the borders of box elements, separately for top border, bottom border, left border and right border. You can set the thickness or width, color and style (such as dotted) of each border. == Border style == * {{CSS:property|border-top-style }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-top-style CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-right-style }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-right-style CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-bottom-style}} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-bottom-style CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-left-style }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-left-style CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-style}} The following values are valid for the border style properties:
  • {{CSS:value|none}}
  • {{CSS:value|hidden}} CSS2.1
  • {{CSS:value|dotted}}
  • {{CSS:value|dashed}}
  • {{CSS:value|solid}}
  • {{CSS:value|double}}
  • {{CSS:value|groove}}
  • {{CSS:value|ridge}}
  • {{CSS:value|inset}}
  • {{CSS:value|outset}}
CSS rule: p { border-style-top: dotted; border-style-right: solid; border-style-bottom: dashed; border-style-left: groove; padding: 0.5em /* Leave a gap between the content and the borders. */ } Sample HTML:

Different borders can be set on the four sides of an element.

{{CSS:rendered|1=

Different borders can be set on the four sides of an element.

}} == Border width == * {{CSS:property|border-top-width }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-top-width CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-top-width CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-right-width }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-right-width CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-right-width CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-bottom-width}} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-bottom-width CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-bottom-width CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-left-width }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-left-width CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-left-width CSS2.1] The border width properties can be set to any non-negative [[CSS Programming/Lengths|length]] or one of the three keyword values {{CSS:value|thin}}, {{CSS:value|medium}} and {{CSS:value|thick}}. A {{CSS:value|thick}} border is guaranteed to be at least as wide as a {{CSS:value|medium}} border, which in turn is at least as wide as a {{CSS:value|small}} border. CSS rules: p { border-style:solid; padding:0.5em /* Leave a gap between the content and the borders. */ } #para1 { border-width-top:0; border-width-right:thin; border-width-bottom:medium; border-width-left:thick } #para2 { border-width-top:0.25em; border-width-right:0.5em; border-width-bottom:0.75em; border-width-left:1em } Sample HTML:

The border on three sides of this paragraph are specified by keywords. The top border is zero width.

This paragraph's borders are given as lengths, increasing in quarter em increments.

{{CSS:rendered|1=

The border on three sides of this paragraph are specified by keywords. The top border is zero width.

This paragraph's borders are given as lengths, increasing in quarter em increments.

}} If the border style for a side has been set to {{CSS:value|none}} the width for that border is considered to be zero regardless of the value set for the side's border width. CSS rules: p { border-style:solid; border-width:1em; padding:0.5em /* Leave a gap between the content and the borders. */ } #para2 { border-style-left:none } Sample HTML:

This paragraph has a solid 1em border.

The left border of this paragraph has been set to none. Notice that the border width has effectively been set to zero.

{{CSS:rendered|1=

This paragraph has a solid 1em border.

The left border of this paragraph has been set to none. Notice that the border width has effectively been set to zero.

}} == Border color == * {{CSS:property|border-top-color }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-top-color CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-right-color }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-right-color CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-bottom-color}} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-bottom-color CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-left-color }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-left-color CSS2.1] The border color properties may be set to any [[CSS Programming/Color|CSS color]] or the keyword {{CSS:value|transparent}}. If no color is specified the border color properties default to the value of the {{CSS:property|color}} for the element. Example 1 CSS rule: p { border-style: solid; border-width: 2em; border-color-top: red; border-color-right: green; border-color-bottom: blue; border-color-left: yellow; padding: 0.5em; /* Leave a gap between the content and the borders. */ width: 10em /* Narrow the box a bit. */ } Sample HTML:

For example the border of this box should have four different colours.

Example rendering: {{CSS:rendered|1=
For example the border of this box should have four different colours.
}} Example 2 CSS rules: p { border-style: solid; border-width: 2em; padding: 0.5em /* Leave a gap between the content and the borders. */ } #para1 { color: red } #para1 { color: green } Sample HTML:

This paragraph has red text and a red border.

This paragraph has green text and a green border.

Example rendering: {{CSS:rendered|1=

This paragraph has red text and a red border.

This paragraph has green text and a green border.

}} == Shorthand properties == * {{CSS:property|border-top }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-top CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-top CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-right }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-right CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-right CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-bottom}} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-bottom CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-bottom CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-left }} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-left CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-left CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-color}} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-color CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-color CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-width}} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-width CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-width CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border-style}} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border-style CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border-style CSS2.1] * {{CSS:property|border}} W3C Specification [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS1#border CSS1] [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#propdef-border CSS2.1] h1 { border: black solid thin; } Creates a black line around the content and padding of all {{HTML:element|h1}} elements. In this example the first value is the color, the second value is the line type and the third value is the line thickness. The values for the individual properties may appear in any order. The following two rules are equivalent to the previous rule. h1 { border: solid black thin; } h1 { border: thin black solid; } ==Border radius== [http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/#the-border-radius Border radius] styles are a part of the [http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/ CSS3 background and borders module]. Currently border-radius is supported by WebKit (Safari, Chrome ''et al.'') & Presto (Opera). Gecko (Firefox, Iceweasel) supports it with the -moz- prefix and slightly different syntax. Trident (Internet Explorer) will support it in the next version, version 5 (IE 9). WebKit has only recently supported it without prefix, so designers may wish to keep the -webkit- prefix in their sheets for backwards compatibility for a little while longer. Syntax: 
border-radius: [  |  ]{1,4} [ / [  |  ]{1,4} ]?;

border-top-left-radius: [  |  ] [  |  ]?;
border-top-right-radius: [  |  ] [  |  ]?;
border-bottom-right-radius: [  |  ] [  |  ]?;
border-bottom-left-radius: [  |  ] [  |  ]?;
Border radius takes at least 1 length per argument for the length of the radius of that corner. Two radii with a / between indicate that it is an ellipse. {| class="wikitable" Syntax for each layout engine |- ! CSS3 ! WebKit ! Gecko ! Presto ! Trident |- | border-radius | border-radius | -moz-border-radius | border-radius | border-radius |- | border-top-left-radius | border-top-left-radius | -moz-border-radius-topleft | border-top-left-radius | border-top-left-radius |- | border-top-right-radius | border-top-right-radius | -moz-border-radius-topright | border-top-right-radius | border-top-right-radius |- | border-bottom-right-radius | border-bottom-right-radius | -moz-border-radius-bottomright | border-bottom-right-radius | border-bottom-right-radius |- | border-bottom-left-radius | border-bottom-left-radius | -moz-border-radius-bottomleft | border-bottom-left-radius | border-bottom-left-radius |}
div { border-radius: 10px; -moz-border-radius: 10px; }
Taking an earlier example: p { border-style: solid; border-width: 2em; border-color-top: red; border-color-right: green; border-color-bottom: blue; border-color-left: yellow; padding: 0.5em; /* Leave a gap between the content and the borders. */ width: 10em /* Narrow the box a bit. */ border-radius: 2em; } Sample HTML:

For example the border of this box should have four different colours and rounded corners.

Example rendering: {{CSS:rendered|1=
For example the border of this box should have four different colours and rounded corners.
}} The border radius can be applied to any type of border the designer wishes (though care must be taken that it looks good):
  • {{CSS:value|none}}
  • {{CSS:value|hidden}} CSS2.1
  • {{CSS:value|dotted}}
  • {{CSS:value|dashed}}
  • {{CSS:value|solid}}
  • {{CSS:value|double}}
  • {{CSS:value|groove}}
  • {{CSS:value|ridge}}
  • {{CSS:value|inset}}
  • {{CSS:value|outset}}
===Mixed radii=== The radii of the 4 corners need not be the same length. You can mix and match any combination of radii you wish.
This div is suited for the top of a web page. Putting a '''0''' in without a unit indicates that no radius is to be applied.
This div is suited for the top of a web page. Putting a '''0''' in without a unit indicates that no radius is to be applied.
Conversely, this one is suited for the bottom of a page.
Conversely, this one is suited for the bottom of a page.
You can also make something fancy.
You can also make something fancy.
===Border radius ellipses=== Giving two lengths in an argument separated by a / will produce an ellipse for that corner or corners.
A div with border-radius: 5px / 10px;.
A div with border-radius: 5px / 10px;.
==Border image== TBD ==Collapsing border== For collapsing borders in tables, see chapter [[../Tables/]]. ==External links== * [http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/box.html#border-properties 8.5 Border properties] at Cascading Style Sheets Level 2 Revision 1 (CSS 2.1) Specification, w3.org [[Category:Cascading Style Sheets|Borders]]

revision.comment: more
/* GROUP PO: Special stamps used only in Post Offices. */ --~~~~
revision.text:
= Australia = Starting with the first meter in 1927 Australia used license numbers rather than meter numbers in a complex series of steps: ::1st series (1927): A1-A9 through Z1–Z9 ::2nd series (1930): 10–999 ::3rd series (1949): A10-A99 through Z10-Z99 ::4th series (1956): AA1-AZ9 through ZA1-ZZ9 ::5th series (1966): 10A-99A through 10Z-99Z ::6th series (1969): 2A1-2Z9 through 9A1-2Z9 Since 1969 manufacturer-assigned meter numbers began replacing the license numbers in the stamps. The meter number with prefix can resemble a license number, and the two can be confused. Additionally, many meters with license numbers also show a manufacturer’s prefix. License numbers are occasionally found colorless on a solid ground. This variety is not recognized in the listings. Other varieties worth noting but which are not cataloged are: :{| | • TM varieties such as inverts, negative lettering | • TMs containing “RELIEF” indicating a meter on loan while a customer’s machine is being serviced |- | • TMs containing “TRIAL” indicating a meter in live testing | • TMs containing “DATE POSTED” instead of a town name |- | • Meter numbers boxed or unboxed | • £sd value figures with capital or lower case pence indicator (D/d) with or without a dot below |- | • Variable size digits in the F/V on fixed value (FV) and limited value (LV) machines | • Date with month in letters, Arabic digit, or Roman numeral |} The stamps are grouped according to appearance and usage: : '''A''' – Upright rectangle with straight-line frame : '''B''' – Curved ribbon frame : '''C''' – Flag inside wide rectangle with simulated perforation frame : '''D''' – Straight-line frame containing large map of country : '''E''' – Frameless rectangle with pictorial design at left : '''F''' – Frameless rectangle with flowers at sides : '''G''' – Wide rectangle with kangaroo design and straight or dashed-line frame or with-out frame : '''H''' – Square with simulated perforation frame : '''I''' – Horizontal rectangle with straight-line frame : '''J''' – Square with herringbone pattern at sides : '''K''' – Square frank made up of mostly horizontal lines : '''L''' – Horizontal frameless frank with Koala bear : '''M''' – Designs containing a data matrix field (2D barcode) : '''PO''' – Special stamps for Post Office use The country converted from Sterling (£sd) to decimal currency on 1 October 1965. ---- NOTES: Variable rate Post office stamps with pre-printed animal designs were introduced in 1993. The stamps do not include a post office ID or a date. They are not covered in this catalog. Meters were used extensively for Railway Parcel Post in Australia. These stamps are not federal government issues and are not covered in this catalog. For specialized information about the meter stamps of Australia, see ''History of the Franking Machine in Australia'', by Richard Peck, ''Australian Postage Label & Meter Catalogue'', by Richard Peck, ''Collect Meter Stamps, Part 1'' and ''Part 2'', by Richard Peck, ''Profiles of Australian Franking Machines and Postage Meters'' a CD publication by Richard Peck, and ''Handbuch der Australischen Absenderfreistempel und Machinen'' by Heinz Bossert. ---- == GROUP A: Upright to nearly square frank with straight-line outer border and separate circular TM ==
[[File:Australia A01.jpg|left|315px]] '''A0.1. Neopost"''' (FV), 1927. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][Extremely rare, one example known. Value uncertain, perhaps $1000] : Upright design with large circle containing the value figure. : Large "POSTAGE PAID" nearly surrounds the value figure. : L# in circle between value figure and "AUSTRALIA" in the bottom panel. : This is a locally engraved die used for several months by the : Neopost agency until factory dies arrived from England in 1928. : TM: BIC :::::::::::::::[[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|17px]]Value: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]1½d [[File:Australia stamp type A1.jpg|left|340px]] [[File:Australia A1c.jpg|right|317px]] '''A1. Neopost"''' (FV, LV-2/3/6/8), 1928. : Similar to Type A0.1 but "POSTAGE PAID" is smaller, : the license number is in an oval rather than a circle, : and "AUSTRALIA" has a curved top. : TM: DC, BIC : £sd values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]1, 1½, 2, 2½, 3, 3½, 4, 5, 6, 6½, 7, 8, 9, 11, 1/- [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]][$10] : £sd values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]2/-, 4/- [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$100] ::::::::::::::: Decimal values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 12, 13, 17, 18 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]][$20] ::::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. Value figures with fragment of simulated perforation below ::::::::::::::::::: '''b'''. License number with “N” prefix ::::::::::::::::::: '''c'''. TM with double inner and outer rims and negative lettering. The license number also is in negative figures. (720) ::::::::::::::::::: '''d'''. License number in negative figures but TM is normal DC. (NB13) [[File:Australia A2.jpg|left|336px]] '''A2. Universal Postal Frankers “Midget”''' (LV-2/3/5), 1928. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$15] : Similar to Type A0.1 but frank is nearly square. : TM: normally DC : £sd values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]½d to 1/- ::::::::::::::::::: '''a.''' V/F not in oval ::::::::::::::::::: '''b.''' With rays emanating from the oval containing the meter number. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$25] ::::::::::::::::::: '''c.''' TM: SC (L# X6) ::::::::::::::::::: '''d.''' TM without outer rim (L# Q4) [[File:Australia A3 color.jpg|left|330px]]
'''A3. Universal Postal Frankers “Multi-Value”''' (MV), 1936. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$10] : With POSTAGE PAID in curved panel above circle. : L# usually at lower right of circle but can be at lower : left or split between the two sides. : TM: DC : £sd V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]0 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]0/0 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]0/0(½) [[File:Australia A4.jpg|left|314px]] '''A4. Universal Postal Frankers “Multi-Value”''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$20] : As Type A3 but sides of inner circle cut out to : make room for larger V/F. L# V88 only seen. : TM: DC : £sd V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]-/-0/- : Decimal V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]=0.oo [[File:Australia stamp type A5.jpg|left|335px]]
'''A5. Universal Postal Frankers “Multi-Value”''' (MV), 1948. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$5] : As Type A3 but with semi-circle open at the bottom instead of circle. : L# at lower right. : TM: DC : £sd V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]0 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]0/0½ [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]00/0½ : Decimal V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]=0.00 [[File:Australia A6.jpg|left|317px]] '''A6. Roneo Neopost''' (LV-6/8), 1948. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$25] : Unique design with vertical lines throughout. : POSTAGE PAID in straight panel at top with : AUSTRALIA in curved panel below it. : Value at bottom center. L# ST4 only. : TM: DC : £sd value: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]5d seen : Decimal values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]03, 04, 05, 06, 07, 09, 10, 15, 20, 25 [[File:Australia stamp type A7.jpg|left|324px]] '''A7. Neopost “Frankmaster 305”''' (MV), 1956. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$5] : Frank with vertical lines at sides. : POST PAID in curved panel at top, AUSTRALIA at bottom. : “RN” prefix at left, L# at right. : TM: DC : £sd V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]=0/= = : Decimal V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]=0.00 [[File:Australia stamp type A8.jpg|left|385px]] '''A8. Pitney Bowes “Simplex"''' (LV-24/25), 1951. : Almost identical to type A5 but smaller frank, and spacing : between TM and frank wider. L#, or M# with “PB” or “S” prefix : or without prefix. : TM: DC : £sd values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]½d to 1/-, 2/1 : Decimal values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]'''.'''01 to .25 ---- == GROUP B: Outer frame of frank is curved ribbon ==
[[File:Australia B1.jpg|left|319px]] '''B1. Roneo Neopost'''' (LV-6/8), 1948. : Kangaroo in center. ID# with boxed “N” and later “VE”, “VX”, and "WA" prefixes. : TM: DC, SC : £sd Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]1d to 2/- : £sd Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]4/-, 6/- [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|8px]][$150] : Decimal Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|13px]]01 to 25 ::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. Kangaroo removed (L# GG8) ::::::::::::::::: '''b'''. Without box around "N" prefix ::::::::::::::::: '''c'''. With a small segment of simulated perforations below the value figure. These appear on stamps with "WA" prefix that had British type value slugs. They are known used between 1959 and 1965.
